bioghist.p: Norman H. Strouse was born in Olympia, Washington, in 1906. Strouse worked for 40 years at the J. Walter Thompson Advertising agency. In 1955 he was promoted to president, and was made chief executive in 1960 and was chairman from 1964 until he retired in 1968. During his tenure in charge of the agency, then the world's largest, billings nearly tripled, and he was credited with modernizing organization and management. He was also chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the recipient of advertising's Gold Medal Award. After retiring in 1968, Strouse focused on his hobby of collecting rare books, fine printing and bindings. He specialized in books by Thomas Carlyle, works bound by Thomas Bird Moser and 12th- to 16th-century illuminated manuscripts. He and his wife, Charlotte, founded the Silverado Museum in St. Helena, dedicated to Robert Louis Stevenson, with more than 6,000 books and other items. He also wrote four books, including How to Build a Poor Man's Morgan Library.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscript letters of Presidents of the United States. Presidents represented include George Washington, John Adams, Millard Filmore, Ulysses S. Grant, Grover Cleveland, Theodore Roosevelt, William Taft, Herbert Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, and John F. Kennedy. First Ladies represented include Grace Coolidge, Florence Harding, Lou Henry Hoover, Jacqueline B. Kennedy, Patricia Nixon, and Eleanor Roosevelt. The collection also includes published volumes with inscriptions by Theodore Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, Herbert Hoover, Lyndon B. Johnson, John F. Kennedy, and Richard Nixon. Additional items in the collection include: printed copies of "Report upon Weights and Measures," 1821, and "Eulogy on James Madison," 1836, both signed by John Quincy Adams; an autograph book with signatures of presidents, cabinet secretaries, senators, and other politicians; Bushrod Washington's Supreme Court Commission, signed by John Adams, 1798; a framed photograph of Norman Strouse; and a signed framed photograph of Herbert Hoover. Also included is the Burpee collection of Lincoln documents, primarily letters received by Lincoln which include notes about his intended response and his endorsement on the reverse. Many of the letters concern appointments. There is also a Navy Commission signed by Lincoln. Additional materials include: correspondence and notes related to provenance of autograph collections at the Free Library of Philadelphia; auction catalogs; transcriptions of letters of George Washington (originals not in the collection); and newspapers related to the shooting of James Garfield.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
